Dear Mrs. Smillie:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
 How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
 Specific time frames for each violation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days.
FOR CWL ONLY
Please note that violations of any licensing rules are also violations of the MISEP and
your contract.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager, Jessica VandenHeuvel, at (616) 204-
6992.

ALLEGATION:
Agency placed youth in an illegal placement.
INVESTIGATION:
Foster Care supervisor was interviewed face-to-face at the agency on April 25,
2022. Foster Care supervisor reported that Youth A is currently placed in a licensed
foster home. Youth A was placed in licensed foster home on April 21, 2022. Prior to
that placement Youth A was in a sibling visit/respite visit with the adoptive parents of
his half siblings. The sibling visit/respite visit began on April 11, 2022. Foster Care
supervisor stated the agency has faced challenges with maintaining placement for
Youth A. Foster Care supervisor stated the agency was able to arrange short-term
placements with licensed foster homes. Foster care supervisor stated one of the
short-term placements (Placement 2) located in Evart, MI ended up keeping Youth A
for much longer than originally anticipated. While in that licensed foster home Youth
A had two incidents at school involving other students whose parents threatened to
press charges against him. In addition, there was an incident involving an elderly
neighbor where he broke into her home and stole money. Foster care supervisor
stated the assigned Foster Care worker (FCW) picked up Youth A on April 1, 2022,
and brought him to the agency. Foster care supervisor stated the agency was
sending multiple emails each day and placing phone calls in an attempt to locate a
2

residential bed for Youth A in addition to trying to locate a temporary placement to
ensure Youth A was not staying in their office. Foster care supervisor stated
Muskegon DHS assisted and was able to secure a temporary respite placement for
the weekend of April 8, 2022, through April 10, 2022. Foster care supervisor stated
during respite Youth A had access to a cell phone and was looking up pornography
while in Meijers. Foster care supervisor stated the respite provider dropped Youth A
off at their agency on Monday, April 11, 2022. Foster care supervisor stated she
contacted the adoptive parents of Youth A’s half siblings who she had worked with in
the past in an attempt to locate relatives of Youth A. Foster care supervisor reported
half sibling’s adoptive parents had a relationship with Youth A and inquired what was
going on with him. Foster care supervisor stated she advised Youth A was currently
sitting in their office and the agency was attempting to locate placement. Foster care
supervisor stated half sibling’s adoptive mother indicated she planned on contacting
her husband to determine if it was possible if they could take him. Half sibling’s
adoptive mother advised she was not sure if their foster home license had closed or
if it was still open but thought it could be considered a sibling visit/respite visit.
Foster care supervisor stated they were under the impression that Bethany Christian
Services Holland (BCS Holland) would contact half sibling’s adoptive parents to
discuss re-opening their foster home license and follow up but that did not happen.
Foster care supervisor stated BCS Holland did not agree with re-opening the foster
home license due to concerns with Youth A’s behavior and concern regarding other
children in the home.
Foster care supervisor stated the agency discussed contacting the local court to
inquire about the court ordering Youth A’s placement with half siblings’ adoptive
parents but there was concern because they would not receive the DOC rate and
treatment foster care would not be able to continue. Foster care supervisor stated
she and the Chief Administrator participated in meetings with agency upper
management and it was decided that would be considered a last resort.
Licensing supervisor was interviewed face-to-face at the agency on April 25, 2022.
Licensing supervisor stated due to ongoing behaviors in that home, school and
community the licensed foster parent put in his 2 weeks’ notice to have Youth A
moved. Licensing supervisor reported she worked diligently and was able to locate a
licensed foster home (Placement 3) that previously had placement of Youth A and
agreed she would allow Youth A to be placed with her on a short-term basis until a
residential bed could be located. Licensing supervisor reported the agency was
given a 2-day notice that Youth A would need to be moved from the home. Licensing
supervisor stated the agency faced challenges locating a placement due to Youth
A’s behaviors and the need for a safety plan that included constant monitoring.
Licensing Supervisor stated she looked up the status of their foster home license
and determined it had been closed. Licensing supervisor stated the license had
been through Bethany Christian Services Holland . Licensing supervisor stated the
agency had been in contact with BCS Holland to coordinate to re-open the foster
home license. Licensing supervisor stated if BCS Holland re-opened the foster home
3

license an addendum would be needed but if Bethany Christian Services Muskegon
(BCS Muskegon) were to re-open the foster home license a full 3130 would be
needed. Licensing supervisor stated they were prepared to do the 3130 but prior to
that occurring the half sibling’s adoptive parents contacted them and reported they
no longer wanted Youth A in their home due to his behaviors. Licensing supervisor
stated BCS Holland was not willing to re-open the foster home license and then
immediately transfer it to BCS Muskegon. Licensing supervisor stated Youth A was
moved from the sibling visit/respite visit on April 20, 2022. Licensing supervisor
stated the agency is facing challenges in locating a residential placement due to
Youth A’s sexual behaviors, the amount of supervision he needs as well as a lack of
available residential beds. Licensing supervisor stated they were under the
impression it was acceptable to have Youth A in the placement as long as it did not
exceed 14 days. Foster care supervisor stated the agency was actively seeking
alternative placement but ran into roadblocks.
Foster Care worker (FCW) was interviewed via telephone on May 24, 2022. FCW
stated Youth A displayed challenging behaviors and the agency struggled to
maintain placements for him. FCW stated the adoptive parents of Youth A’s half
siblings were willing to take Youth A into their home on a temporary basis until a
residential placement opened. FCW confirmed Youth A’s previous placement was
no longer willing to keep him at the time he went to the home of the adoptive parents
of his half siblings.
This consultant had a conversation with Chief Administrator on April 13, 2022. This
consultant advised that, according to policy, Youth A is not considered to be a
relative of his half siblings’ adoptive parents. As a result, the current placement with
the adoptive parents of Youth A’s half siblings is not an approved placement. The
placement would need to be court ordered or they would need to re-open the foster
home license. A follow up conversation with Chief Administrator took place on April
20, 2022. Chief Administrator stated the agency did not obtain a court order for
Youth A to remain in the home of his half siblings’ adoptive parents. In addition, the
adoptive parents of Youth A’s half siblings were not able to re-open their foster home
license, yet the agency continued placement of Youth A in the home.
Documents Reviewed:
 MiSACWIS Case File: Social work contact dated April 11, 2022, at 2:01pm
FC Supervisor discusses safety plan with adoptive parents of half siblings
while Youth A is in the home. In addition, there was discussion about
rearranging sleeping arrangements to accommodate Youth A. There is also
discussion about reopening the foster home license.
 MISACWIS Provider record of adoptive parents of half siblings verifying foster
home license was closed effective March 8, 2022.
 MiSACWIS Case File regarding placements:
o Placement 1: Youth A placed in licensed foster home from March 1,
2021-January 5, 2022.
4

o Placement 2: Youth A placed in licensed foster home January 5, 2022-
April 1, 2022.
o Placement 3: Youth A placed licensed foster home April 1, 2022-April
20, 2022. Note during interviews and conversations with agency, they
reported Youth A was dropped off at agency by Placement 3 on April
11 stating he could no longer reside in the home.
o Placement 4: Youth A placed in licensed foster home licensed foster
home on April 21, 2022.
APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.12404 Placement.
(1) An agency shall only place a child with an adult who is
legally related to the child, is a legal custodian, or in a
licensed foster home, except as permitted in R 400.12709.
ANALYSIS: Agency temporarily placed child with adoptive parents of half
siblings who are no longer licensed. Agency considered it to be
a sibling visit/respite visit. However, it could not be considered a
sibling visit/ respite because Youth A no longer had an intact
placement he would return to.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
IV. RECOMMENDATION
I recommend upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan no change be
made to the license status of this child placing agency.
